Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: This action is brought under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, § 28, and other applicable law.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified if the moving party demonstrates a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child. [See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000).]

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified if the moving party demonstrates a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child. [See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000).]
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: This case does not involve a modification of an existing G.L. c. 208, § 28 custody order or articulate the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard under § 28. Instead, it addresses an initial custody determination in a nonmarital child case under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and expressly declines to apply or discuss the substantial-change standard for modification proceedings. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific § 28 modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: "We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a)."

*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified if the moving party demonstrates a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child. [See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000).]
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10, for a child born out of wedlock. It does not involve or discuss modification of an existing custody order under G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it articulate the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard. Accordingly, it cannot serve as authority for the specific modification principle stated in the proposition.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .” R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. See Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987); Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. at 925; Freedman v. Freedman, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 519, 522 (2000), and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations, and the court must assess factors such as the child’s safety, well-being, and stability when evaluating custody arrangements. [See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).]
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that, under G.L. c. 208, § 30, ‘cause shown’ for removal means that removal must be in the child’s best interests and that this best-interests standard governs the court’s determination. The court further explains that the best interests inquiry is grounded in the individual child’s needs and circumstances, and in applying it the judge considered safety, well-being, education, stability, relationships with both parents, and household conditions. Thus, Mason v. Coleman directly supports the proposition that custody-related determinations (here, removal in a joint custody context) are governed by a best interests standard that requires assessment of the child’s safety, well-being, and stability.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… [a] minor child… shall not… be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.… ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’… [T]he judge… determined that removal to New Hampshire… was not in the best interests of the children….”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations, and the court must assess factors such as the child’s safety, well-being, and stability when evaluating custody arrangements. [See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).]
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody determinations the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and general welfare, and it applies that standard to evaluate custody and visitation. The court emphasizes welfare, happiness, minimizing disruption, and a healthy environment for the children’s growth and development—factors that encompass safety, well-being, and stability—when affirming the award of sole custody and reduced visitation. Thus, it directly supports the proposition that the best interests standard governs custody decisions and requires assessment of such factors.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.proposition: When a parent’s physical or mental health deteriorates such that it impacts their ability to safely and consistently care for a child, courts have found such circumstances sufficient to justify modification. [See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).]
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.support_reasoning: The opinion in Williams v. Massa is a divorce judgment appeal primarily addressing property division, alimony/child support, fees, and initial custody orders. The only modification-related issue it decides is procedural: that future changes in custody must occur via a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, not by motion. The court does not discuss a parent’s physical or mental health deterioration as a basis for modification, nor does it articulate any standard that such deterioration, impacting parenting ability, justifies modification. Thus it does not support the stated proposition.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: When a parent’s physical or mental health deteriorates such that it impacts their ability to safely and consistently care for a child, courts have found such circumstances sufficient to justify modification. [See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).]
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is about relocation and modification of custody, but it does not involve or discuss any deterioration in a parent’s physical or mental health as a basis for modification. The court actually rejects the claimed change in circumstances and reverses a custody change, emphasizing that the working, healthy custodial parent remained an appropriate primary caretaker. Thus, Rosenthal v. Maney does not support the proposition that deterioration in a parent’s health justifying modification was present or upheld in this case.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker.”

*Adoption of Oliver*, 42 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts also disfavor custodial arrangements where a minor child feels undue responsibility for the care of a parent, as such scenarios can place inappropriate emotional and physical burdens on the child that may impede their development. [See *Adoption of Oliver*, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 311 (1997).]
*Adoption of Oliver*, 42 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt deals exclusively with extradition and the limited scope of habeas review in the asylum state, not with child custody, adoption, or the emotional burdens placed on a child caring for a parent. There is no discussion of custodial arrangements, child development, or related best-interest-of-the-child principles, so the case does not support the cited proposition.
*Adoption of Oliver*, 42 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Once the governor has granted extradition, a court considering release on habeas corpus can do no more than decide (a) whether the extradition documents on their face are in order; (b) whether the petitioner has been charged with a crime in the demanding state; (c) whether the petitioner is the person named in the request for extradition; and (d) whether the petitioner is a fugitive.”
